Criminal Appeal No. 468 of 1986t, decided on April 29, 1988 Editorial note.-Since the number of issues involved and aspects considered are several, the headnote ha,s been sub-divided as per scheme of the headnote given below. Since all the points have not been covered in each of the judgments, the headnote should be read as a whole. The leading judgment is by Mukharji , J . for himaelf, Oza and Natarajan , JJ. Ranganath Misra, J . has concurred with 1\1:ukharji, J. with a separate opinion and has differed with him on certain aapecta. Oza, J. who is a party to the opinion by Mukharji, J. has yet delivered a short opinion to express his dissent with Mukharji, J. 's opinion and concurrence with Ranganath Misra, J. 's opinion on the issue whether a writ of certiorari by Supreme Court would lie to correct its own error in any judgment or order. Oza. J. has in other respects agreed both with the opinion by Mukharji, J. and the opinion by Ranganath Misra, J. Ray, J. has also concurred both with the opinions by Mukharji, J. and by Ranganath Misra, J. In his short opinion he has set out conclusions on four issues on which according to him both opinions are clearly agreed, But, in fact, regarding the first stated conclusion on issue of writ of certiorari by the Supreme Court to correct its own error Mukharji, J. and Ranganath Misra, J. differ. The pcxition of Ray, J. is also not clear on the issue whether power of review can be exercised by the Supreme Court in the exercise of inherent power without insisting on a formal application under Article 137. Venkatachaliah, J. has dissented with the majority and he has relied on certain observations of Ranganath Misra, J. Ranganathan, J. has partly dissented with the majority in that though he agrees with the majority that the transfer of the case of the petitioner to the High Court was improper, he haa not agreed in upsetting the impugned directions dated Feb. 16, 1984. Precedent Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952 - Section 7(1) - Supreme Court has no jurisdiction to suo motu direct withdrawal of case from Court of Special Judge and transfer thereof to High Court for speedier trial (Per majority, Venkatachaliah, J. contra) Constitution of India - Articles 134, 136 and ,137 - Directions of a Bench (of five Judges) of Supreme Court given suo motu in violation of fundamental rights and principles of natural justice and per incuriam were without jurisdiction and nullity - Such directions even if subsequently questioned in another appeal instead of in a review petition under Article 137, can be set aside by another Bench (of seven Judges in this case) of the Court ex debito justitiae in exercise of its inherent power (Per majority, Venkata- chaliah and Ranganathan, JJ. contra) F AcrS : The appellant remained the Chief Minister of the State of Maharashtra from 1980 till January 20, 1982. The respondent, a member of a rival political party, filed a complaint before the Additional Metro- politan Magistrate, Bombay against the appellant and other known and unknown persons for alleged offences under Sectiom 161 and 165 of the Indian Penal Code and Section 5 of the Prevention of Corruption Act as also under Sections 384 and 420 read with Sections 109 and 120-B of the Indian Penal Code. Thereafter, a criminal revision application was filed. The Governor of Maharashtra later accorded sanction and the respondent filed a fresh complaint, this time in the Court of the Special Judge of Bombay, alleging the commission of those offences which had formed the subject- matter of the complaint before the Magistrate . On receiving summons from the Court of the particular Special Judge, the appellant took the stand that the said Special Judge had no juri5.d1ction to ePtertain the complaint in view of Section 7 of the Criminal Law Amendment Act and cognizance could not be taken on a private complaint. These objections were overruled by the Special Judge by order dated October 20, 1982, and the case was set down for recording evidence of the prosecution. The Criminal Revision Petition of the accused against the order of the Special Judge was rejected by the Bombay High Court and it held that a private complaint was maintainable and in view of the notification specifying a particular Special Judge for the offences in question there was no basis for the objections. The Supreme Court granted special leave to the accused against the decision of the High Court that a private complaint was maintainable. In the mean time, objection raised before the Special Judge that without sanction the accused, who still continued to be a member of Legislative Assembly, could not be prosecuted came to be accepted by the Special Judge. The complainant filed a criminal revision application before the High Court questioning that order. The Supreme Court granted special leave against the dec~ion that sanction was necessary. Both the criminal appeals and the tra.nsf erred criminal revision were heard together by a five-Judge Bench of the Supreme Court but the two appeals were disposed of by two separate judgments delivered on February 16, 1984 viz. A. R. Antulay v. R. S. Nayak, (1984) 2 sec 500: 1984 sec (Cri) 277 and R S. Nayak v. A. R. Antulay, (1984) 2 sec 183: 1984 SCC (Cri) 172 respectively. In the latter decision a Constitution Bench of the Supreme Court held that an MLA is not a public servant and therefore no sanction is required for hls prosecution. The Court accordingly set aside the order of discharge of the accused made by the Special Judge and directed that the trial shall proceed further from the stage where the accused was discharged. The Court further observed that by the pro- secution launched again&t the appellant, his character and integrity came under a cloud, that nearly 2 ½ years had rolled by and the case had not moved further and that an expeditious trial which is a mandate of Article 21 was in the interest of both the prosecution and the ac.cused. With that view the Court gave a further direction [dated February 16, 1984: (1984) 2 sec 183 at 243] withdrawing the special cases against the appellant pending in the Court of Special Judge and transferring the same to the High Court of Bombay with a request to the Chief Justice to assign the cases to a sitting Judge of the High Court for holding the trial from day to day. Pursuant to this direction, the cases came to be posted for trial before a Judge of the High Court and the trial opened on April 9, 1984. The appellant then filed a writ petition before the Supreme Court under Article 32. A two-Judge Bench of the Court by its order dated April 17, 1984, in A. R. Antulay v. Union of India (see Annexure) dismissed the petition by observing inter alia that the writ petition challenging the validity of the order and judgment passed by the Supreme Court as nullity or otherwise incorrect cannot be entertained, and the dismissal of the writ petition will not prejudice the right of the petitioner to approach the Court with an appropriate review petition or to file any other application which he may be entitled in law to file. Thereafter several witnesses were examined. Forty-three draft charges were placed for consideration on behalf of the prosecution and the trial judge framed 21 charges and recorded an order of discharge in respect of the remaining 22. At the instance of the complainant, the respondent, the matter came before the Supreme Court in appeal on special leave and a two-Judge Bench, by fudgment dated April 17, 1986 [(1986J 2 SCC 716] set aside the order of discharge in regard to the several offences excepting extortion and directed the trial iudge to frame charges for the same. Subsequently, the then Judge of the High Court (P. S. Shah, J.) dealing with the cases by his order dated July 24, 1986 framed 79 charges and rejected the application of the accused for proceeding against the alleged co-conspirators. The appellant challenged the order by filing a special leave petition (No. 2519 of 1986) before the Supreme Court wherein he questioned the High Court's jurisdiction to try the case in violation of Articles 14 and 21 and the provisions of Act 46 of 1952. A two-Judge Bench, of which Mukharji, J. was a member, granted the special leave, formulated several questions that arose for consideration and referred the matter for hearing by a Bench of seven Judges of the Court. Before the present seven-Judge Bench two quec,tions arose : I. Whether the directions of the Constitution Bench of Supreme Court dated February 16, 1984 [R. S. Nayak v. A. R. Antulay, (1984) 2 sec 183, 243: 1984 sec (Cri) 112: (1984) 2 SCR 495] directing the transfer of the case from the Special Judge to the High Court are inoperative, invalid or illegal ; and II. Whether, if so, the Supreme Court can and should recall, withdraw, revoke or set aside the same in the present proceedin~ ? The matters arising in SLP (C--riminal) No. 2518 of 1986 and W. P. (Cri) No. 542 of 1986 were delinked from the present appeal. Allowing the present appeal by a majority of 5: 2 to the effect that all proceedin~ in the matter subsequent to the directions of the Supreme Court on February 16, 1984 be set aside and quashed and that the trial proceed in accordance with law i.e. under the Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952 (see Para 242), the Supreme Court Held: Per Mukharji, Oza and Natarajan, JJ. The directions definitely deprived the appellant of certain rights of appeal and revision and his rights under the Constitution. (Paras 78 and 79) Ex debito justitiae, the Court must, therefore, do justice and the legal wrong that has been caused to the appellant should be remedied. Let that wrong be, remedied. Let right be done and in doing so let no more further injury be caused to public purpose. Accordingly, all proceedings in this matter subsequent to the directions of the Supreme Court on February 16, 1984 are set aside and quashed. The order ta.king cognizance, however, has become final and is unassailable. The trial shall proceed in acccordance with law, that is, under the Act of 1952. (Paras 86, 87 and 10) Per Ranganath Misra, J. (concurring) The Supreme Court did not possess the power to transfer the proceed- ings from the Special Judge to the High Court. It is, therefore, the duty of the Court to rectify the mistake by exercising inherent powers. (Paras 94 and 95) I agree with the ultimate conclusion proposed by Justice Mukbarji. (Para 108) Per Ray, J. (concurring) I agree with the opinion expressed by Justice Mukharji in the judgment as well as the additional opinion given by Justice Misra in his separate judgment. (Para 112) Per Venkatachaliah, J. (dissenting) It would be wholly erroneous to characterise the directions issued by the five-Judge Bench as a nullity, amenable to be ignored or so declared in a collateral attack. (Para 149) Per Ranganathan, J. (partly dissenting) The direction issued by the Court was not warranted in law, being contrary to the special provisions of the 1952 Act ; it was also not in conformity with the principles of natural justice and unless the direction can be justified with reference to Section 407 of the CrPC, the petitioner's fundamental rights under Articles 14 and 21 can be said to have been infringed by reason of this direction. (Para 216) But this is not one of those cases in which I would consider it appropriate to recaU the earlier direction and order a re-trial of the appellant de novo before a Special Judge. (Para 241) I. VALIDITY AND LEGALITY OF SUPREME COURT'S DIRECTIONS DATED FEBRUARY 16, 1984 A. NAYAK 607 pending trial before Special Judge cannot be transferred to High Court - Bnt can be transferred to another Special Judge - Effect of non obstantc clause in sub-section (1) (Per majority) (2) Criminal Procedure Code, 1973 - Section 407 - Scope - It is subject to overriding provisions of Section 7(1) of Criminal Law Amend- ment Act, 1952 (Per majority) (3) Letters Patent of Bombay High Court - Clause 29 - Power of transfer under, cannot be exercised in violation of Section 7(1) o:e Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952 ( 4) Statute Law - Repeal - Where there is express overriding provision, question of repeal of any provision by that' provision does not arise (5) InterpTetation of Statutes - Literal meaning to be preferred when clear - Resort to golden role or mischief rule only necessary if literal meaning not clear Held: Per Mukharji, Oza and Natarajan, JJ. (Ray, J. concurring) Section 7(1) of the 1952 Act creates a condition which is sine qua non for the trial of offences under Section 6(1) of the said Act. The condition is that notwithstanding anything contained in the Code of Criminal Procedure or any other law, the said offences shall be friable by Special Judges only. By express terms, therefore, it takes away the right to transfer cases contained in the Code to any other court which is not a Special Court and this is notwithstanding anything contained in Sections 406 and 407 of the Code. (Paras 24, 34, 68 and 70) If a case could be transferred under Section 406 of the Code from a Special Judge it could only be transferred to another Special Judge or a court of superior jurisdiction but subordinate to the High Court. No such court exists. Therefore, under this section the power of transfer can only be from one Special Judge to another Special Judge. (Para 28) Gurcharan Das 01.adha v. State of Rajasthan, (1966) 2 SCR 678: AIR 1966 SC 1418 and Romesh Chandra Arora v. State, (1960) 1 SCR 924: 1960 Cri l.J 1 77, referred to Therefore, the order of the Supreme Court transferring the cases to the High Court on February 16, 1984, was not authorised by law, namely, Section 7(1) of the 1952 Act. The Court, by its directions, could not confer jurisdiction on the High Court of Bombay to try any case for which it did not possess such jurisdiction under the scheme of the 1952 Act. lit seems this aspect of Section 7 was not present in the mind of the Court while passing the impugned directions.] (Para 38) Kiran Singh v. In this case in view of the specific language used in Section 7 of the Criminal Law Amendment Act, it is not necessary to consider the other submissions viz. whether the procedure for trial by Special Judges wider the Code has stood repealed or not. The concept of repeal may have no application in this case. It is clear that words should normally be given their ordinary meaning bearing in mind the context. It is only where the literal meaning is not clear that one resorts to the golden rule of interpretation or the mischief rule of interpretation. (Paras 70 and 71) Sussex Peerage Claim, (1844) 11 Ce & Fin 85, and Stowell v. Lord Zouch, 75 ER 536, referred to Cross : Statutory Interpretation, 2nd Edn., p. 36, referred to The submissions regarding the purpose of the Criminal Law Amend- ment Act and the constitutibn of the Special Court and that the powers given in the Criminal Law Amendment Act were sought to be misused by the State Government under the influence of the appellant, are not relevant for the present purpose. These considerations do not authorise the conferring of a special jurisdiction on the High Court not warranted by the Statute. (Para 68) Re the Special Courts Bill, 1978, (1979) 1 SCC 380: (1979) 2 SCR 476 and V. C. Shukla v. State (Delhi Administration), (1980) 2 sec 665: 1980 SCC (Cri) 561 : (1980) 3 SCR 500, distinguished Per Ranganath Misra, J. (concurring) Section 7(1) of the Criminal Law Amendment Act has clearly provided that offences specified in Section 6(1) shall be triable by the Special Judge only and has taken away the power of the courts establishe.d under the Code of Criminal Procedure to try thost> offences. Section 7(1) does not authorise transfer of a case pendin!! in the court of a Special Judge first to the Supreme Court and then to the High Court for trial. As long as Section 7 holds the field it was not open to any court including the Apex Court to act contrary to Section 7(1). (Paras 92, 93 and 94) Raia Soap Factory v. S. P. Shantharaj, (1965) 2 SCR 800: AIR 1965 SC 1449, relied on Kaverappa v. Narayanaswamy, 1962 Mys LJ 1 (Short Notes of Recent Decision), cited The power to transfer a case conferred by the Constitution or by Section 406 of the Code of Criminal Procedure does not specifically relate to the Special Court. Section 406 can be applied on the principle that the Special Judge was a subordinate court for transferring a case from one Special Judge to another Special Judge as that would not contravene the mandate of Section 7(1) of the Act of 1952. (Para 93) Per Ranganathan, J. (concmring) The restriction contained in sub-section (1) of Section 7 of the 1952 Act cannot be placed on the same footing as that in sub-section (2) ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. The power of transfer contained in CrPC cannot be availed of to transfer a case from a Special Judge to any other criminal court or even the High Court. While the requirement of territorial juris- diction is subordinate to Section 406 or 407, the requirement that the trial should be by a Special Judge is not. The case can be transferred only from one Special Judge to another Special Judge; it cannot be transferred even to a High Court Judge except where a High Court Judge is appointed as a Special Judge. A power of transfer postulates that the court to which transfer or withdrawal is sought is competent to exercise jurisdiction over the c.ase. (Para 199) Gurcharan Das Chadha v. State of Rajasthan, (1966) 2 SCR 678 : AIR 1966 SC 1418 and Raja Soap Factory v. S. P. Shantharaj, (1965) 2 SCR 800: AIR 1965 SC 1449, relied on The High Court's power of transfer under Section 407 or Clause 29 of the Letters Patent will neither override, nor even operate consistently with the provisions of the 1952 Act. (Paras 201 and 204) Though the court to which the case has been transferred is a superior court and in fact, the High Court, but the High Court judge is not a person to whom the trial of the case can be assigned under Section 7(1) of the 1952 Act. (Para 202) Suraj Mall Mohta v. Visvanatha Sastri , (1955) 1 SCR 448, 468: AIR 1954 SC 545, relied on Tue 1952 Act sought to expedite the trial of cases involving public servants by the creation of courts presided over by experienced Special Judges to be appointed by the State Government. By virtue of the express and specific words used in Section 7(1) the provisions of other laws in general and CrPC in particular have been made inapplicable. No question arises of any construction being encouraged that is repugnant to the CrPC or involves an implied repeal, pro tanto, of its provisions. (Para 203) Per Venkatachaliah, J. ( dissenting) Even to the extent the argument goes that the High Court under Section 407 CrPC could not withdraw to itself a trial from Special Judge under the 1952 Act, the view of the earlier Bench is a possible view. (Para 166) In view of the difficulties in determining whether an implication of repeal was intended in a particular situation it would be a reasonable pre- sumption that where the legislature desired a repeal, it would have made it plain by express words . (Para 166) B. HIGH COURT'S POWER OF TRANSFER (1) Criminal Law Amendment Act, 1952 - Section 7(1) - Excludes High Court's power to transfer and try a case triable by Special Judge - Neither Article 134(1)(b), of the Constitution, nor Section 374 CrPC, 1973 ----------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------------- Modak, (2008) 1 SCC 1 paras 61, 62 & 63. this judgment is protected by the law declared by the Supreme Court in Eastern Book Company v. (Ranganath Misra and Ray, JJ., concurring) Section 407 of the Code is subject to the overriding mandate of Section 7(1) of the 1952 Act and, hence, it does not permit the High Court to withdraw a case for trial to itself from the Court of Special Judge. Where by a specific clause of a specific statute the power is given for trial by the Special Judge only and transfer can be from one such Judge to another Special Judge, there is no warrant to suggest that the High Court has power to transfer such a case from a Judge under Section 6 of the Act of 1952 to itself. It is not a case of exclusion of the superior courts. (Paras 56, 70 and 72) Article 134(1)(b) does not recognise in every High Court power to withdraw for trial cases from any court subordinate to its authority. At least this article cannot be construed to mean where power to withdraw is restricted, it can be widened by virtue of Article 134(1)(b). (Para 72) Article 21 as recently interpreted safeguards one right of appeal on facts and law. The trial by High Court in the present case cannot be deemed to be one under its 'extraordinary original criminal jurisdiction' which is confined to cases decided under Letters Patent jurisdiction. Therefore a right of appeal as of right is not available to the appellant under Section 374, CrPC. (Paras 64 to 67) Kavasji Pestonji Dalal v. Rustomji Sorabji Jamadar, AIR 1949 Born 42; Sunil Chandra Roy v. State, AIR 1954 Cal 305 (para 15) : 1954 Cri LJ 805; Sasadhar Acharjya v. Sir Charles Tegart, (1930-31) 35 Cal WN 1088; Peoples' Insurance Co. Ltd. v. Sardul Singh Caveeshar, AIR 1961 Punj 87: ILR (1960) 1 Punj 341 and P. P. Front, New Delhi v. K. K. Birla, 1984 Cri LJ 545 (Del), distinguished The creation of a right to an appeal is an act which requires legislative authority, neither an inferior court nor the superior Court nor both combined can create such a right, it being one of limitation and extension of jurisdiction. (Para 57) A. G. of India v. Lachmma Devi, AIR 1986 SC 467 ; Kuchenmeister v. Home Office, (1958) 1 QB 496; Attorney General v. Herman Jame~ Sillem, (1864) 10 HLC 704 (HL) and Isaacs v. Robertson, (1984) 3 All ER 140 (PC), referred to Per Ranganathan, J. But in view of the non obstante clause in Section 7(1) of the Criminal Law Amendment Act, Section 407 will neither override nor even operate consistently with the provisions of the Criminal Law Amendment Act. For the same reason the power of transfer contained in Clause 29 of the Letters Patent cannot be exercised in a manner not contemplated by Section 7(1) of the 1952 Act. (Paras 201 and 204) Not all the judges of the High Court (but only those elevated from the State subordinate judiciary) would fulfil the qualifications prescribed under Section 6(2) of the 1952 Act. Though there is nothing in Sections 6 and 7 read together to preclude altogether the appointment of a judge of the High Court fulfilling the above qualifications as a Special Judge, such is not the contemplation of the Act. Apart from the fact that in this case no appointment of a High Court judge, as a Special Judge, has in fact been made, it is not possible to take the view that the statutory provisions permit the conferment of a jurisdiction to try his case on a High Court Judge as a Special Judge. (Para 197) Per Venkatachaliah, J. The maxim actus curiae neminem gravabit -· an act of the court shall prejudice no man - is founded upon justice and good sense and affords a safe and certain guide for the administration of the law. Therefore injustice done should be corrected by applying the principle actus curiae neminem gravabit - an act of the court should prejudice no one. To own up the mistake when judicial satisfaction is reached does not militate against its status or authority. Perhaps it would enhance both. (Paras 98, 103 and 104) Rodger v. If the words of the statute are in themselves precise and unambiguous, then no more can be necessary than to expound those words in that natural and ordinary sense. The words themselves alone do, in such case, best declare the intention of the lawgiver. But if any doubt arises from the terms employed by the legislature, it has always been held a safe means of collecting the intention, to call in aid the ground and cause of making the statute, and to have recourse to the preamble, which, according to Chief Justice Dyer, Stowell v. He observed that the interpretation of legislation is just a part of the process of being a good lawyer ; a multi-faceted thing, calling for many varied talents ; not a subject which can be confined in rules. When the words are clear nothing remains to be seen. If words are as such ambiguous or doubtful other aids come in. The power of review is conferred on this Court by Article 137 of the Constitution which reads thus : Subject to the provisions of any law made by Parliament or any rules made under Article 145, the Supreme Court shall have power to review any judgment pronounced or order made by it. It is subject not only to the provisions of any law made by Parliament (and there is no such law so far framed) but also to any rules made by this Court under Article 145. This Court has made rules in pursuance of Article 145 which are contained in Order XL in Part VIII of the Supreme Court Rules. Three of these rules are relevant for our present purposes. They read as follows : ( 1 ) The Court may review its judgment or order. but no application for review will be entertained in a civil proceeding except on the ground mentioned in Order XL VII, Rule 1 of the Code, and in a criminal proceeding except on the ground of an error apparent on the face of the record. ( 2) An application for review shall be by a petition, and shall be filed within thirty days from the date of the judgment or order sought to be reviewed. It shall set out clearly the grounds for review. (3) Unless otherwise ordered by the Court an application for review shall be disposed of by circulation without any oral arguments, but the petitioner may supplement his petition by additional written arguments. The Court may either di1'mi&s the petition or direct notice to the opposite party. An application for review shall as far as practicable be circulated to the same judge or Bench of judges that delivered the judgment or order sought to be reviewed. 220.
